zero trust: Zero Trust is a security model that assumes no user or device should be trusted by default.
zero trust security: Zero Trust is a security model that assumes no user or device should be trusted by default.
incident response: Incident response is the process of detecting, managing, and recovering from cybersecurity incidents.
incident handling: Incident response is the process of detecting, managing, and recovering from cybersecurity incidents.
ddos: A DDoS attack floods a system or website with traffic to make it unavailable.
distributed denial of service: A DDoS attack floods a system or website with traffic to make it unavailable.

insider threat: An insider threat occurs when trusted users misuse access to harm an organization.

access control: Access control ensures users can only access resources they are authorized to use.
access management: Access control ensures users can only access resources they are authorized to use.
least privilege: Least privilege means giving users only the minimum access necessary to do their job.
principle of least privilege: Least privilege means giving users only the minimum access necessary to do their job.
secure coding: Secure coding involves writing software to reduce security vulnerabilities.
secure programming: Secure coding involves writing software to reduce security vulnerabilities.
model bias: Model bias occurs when AI outputs unfair results due to biased data or design.
algorithmic bias: Model bias occurs when AI outputs unfair results due to biased data or design.
explainable ai: Explainable AI focuses on making AI decisions understandable to humans.
xai: Explainable AI focuses on making AI decisions understandable to humans.
consent: Consent means users agree to how their personal data is collected and used.
user consent: Consent means users agree to how their personal data is collected and used.
data minimization: Data minimization means collecting only the data that is strictly necessary.
